Use the above equivalence to prove we have a limit.

type:
‚àÄ {J : Type w} {C : Type u} [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{v, u} C] {B : C}
  (F : CategoryTheory.Functor (CategoryTheory.Discrete J) (CategoryTheory.Over B))
  [inst_1 :
    CategoryTheory.Limits.HasLimit (CategoryTheory.Over.ConstructProducts.widePullbackDiagramOfDiagramOver B F)],
  CategoryTheory.Limits.HasLimit F
name: CategoryTheory.Over.ConstructProducts.has_over_limit_discrete_of_widePullback_limit
docString: Use the above equivalence to prove we have a limit.

The limit inferior of the integral of an almost-everywhere measurable sequence of extended nonnegative real-valued functions with respect to a measure is less than or equal to the integral of their limit inferior. In mathematical notation, this is written as:

\[ \int_{\alpha} \liminf_{n \to \infty} f_n(a) \,d\mu(a) \leq \liminf_{n \to \infty} \int_{\alpha} f_n(a) \,d\mu(a) \]

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {m : MeasurableSpace Œ±} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±} {f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí ENNReal},
  (‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), AEMeasurable (f n) Œº) ‚Üí
    ‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), Filter.liminf (fun n => f n a) Filter.atTop ‚àÇŒº ‚â§
      Filter.liminf (fun n => ‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), f n a ‚àÇŒº) Filter.atTop
name: MeasureTheory.lintegral_liminf_le'
docString:
The limit inferior of the integral of an almost-everywhere measurable sequence of extended nonnegative real-valued functions with respect to a measure is less than or equal to the integral of their limit inferior. In mathematical notation, this is written as:

\[ \int_{\alpha} \liminf_{n \to \infty} f_n(a) \,d\mu(a) \leq \liminf_{n \to \infty} \int_{\alpha} f_n(a) \,d\mu(a) \]

This theorem asserts that for any positive real number `y`, the function `x ^ (-y)` tends to `0` as `x` approaches positive infinity. In mathematical terms, it says that the limit as `x` tends to `+‚àû` of `x^(-y)` is `0` for any `y` greater than `0`. This describes how the function behaves at very large values of `x`: as `x` gets larger and larger, `x^(-y)` gets closer and closer to zero, regardless of what positive real value `y` takes.

type: ‚àÄ {y : ‚Ñù}, 0 < y ‚Üí Filter.Tendsto (fun x => x ^ (-y)) Filter.atTop (nhds 0)
name: tendsto_rpow_neg_atTop
docString: This theorem asserts that for any positive real number `y`, the function `x ^ (-y)` tends to `0` as `x` approaches positive infinity. In mathematical terms, it says that the limit as `x` tends to `+‚àû` of `x^(-y)` is `0` for any `y` greater than `0`. This describes how the function behaves at very large values of `x`: as `x` gets larger and larger, `x^(-y)` gets closer and closer to zero, regardless of what positive real value `y` takes.

A Lebesgue Integral from -‚àû to y can be expressed as the sum of one from -‚àû to 0 and 0 to x

type:
‚àÄ {y z : ‚Ñù} (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ENNReal),
  z ‚â§ y ‚Üí ‚à´‚Åª (x : ‚Ñù) in Set.Iic y, f x = (‚à´‚Åª (x : ‚Ñù) in Set.Iio z, f x) + ‚à´‚Åª (x : ‚Ñù) in Set.Icc z y, f x
name: lintegral_Iic_eq_lintegral_Iio_add_Icc
docString: A Lebesgue Integral from -‚àû to y can be expressed as the sum of one from -‚àû to 0 and 0 to x

If $f: (a, \infty) \to \mathbb{R}$, $f'(x)$ exists for all $x \in (a, \infty)$, $g: \operatorname{Im} f \to E$ is continuous and integrable, and $f$ is continuous, tends to infinity, and has an integrable product derivatives $f'(x) \cdot (g \circ f)(x)$, then $\int_{a}^{\infty} f'(x) \cdot (g \circ f)(x) \, dx = \int_{f(a)}^{\infty} g(u) \, du$.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {a : ‚Ñù},
  ContinuousOn f (Set.Ici a) ‚Üí
    Filter.Tendsto f Filter.atTop Filter.atTop ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ioi a, HasDerivWithinAt f (f' x) (Set.Ioi x) x) ‚Üí
        ContinuousOn g (f '' Set.Ioi a) ‚Üí
          MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn g (f '' Set.Ici a) MeasureTheory.volume ‚Üí
            MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn (fun x => f' x ‚Ä¢ (g ‚àò f) x) (Set.Ici a) MeasureTheory.volume ‚Üí
              ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in Set.Ioi a, f' x ‚Ä¢ (g ‚àò f) x = ‚à´ (u : ‚Ñù) in Set.Ioi (f a), g u
name: MeasureTheory.integral_comp_smul_deriv_Ioi
docString: If $f: (a, \infty) \to \mathbb{R}$, $f'(x)$ exists for all $x \in (a, \infty)$, $g: \operatorname{Im} f \to E$ is continuous and integrable, and $f$ is continuous, tends to infinity, and has an integrable product derivatives $f'(x) \cdot (g \circ f)(x)$, then $\int_{a}^{\infty} f'(x) \cdot (g \circ f)(x) \, dx = \int_{f(a)}^{\infty} g(u) \, du$.

This theorem states that if the expression `(f y - f x) / (y - x)` tends to a certain limit as `y` approaches `x` (possibly only from one side or along certain lines), then the same limiting behavior holds for the expression `(f (y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) - d) / (y - x)`. This is essentially saying that adding a small perturbation `(c * (y - x) ^ 2)` to the argument of `f` in the numerator doesn't change the limiting behavior. This theorem is particularly useful in the study of almost everywhere differentiability of monotone functions, where such perturbations often arise.

type:
‚àÄ {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {x a c d : ‚Ñù} {l : Filter ‚Ñù},
  l ‚â§ nhdsWithin x {x}·∂ú ‚Üí
    Filter.Tendsto (fun y => (f y - d) / (y - x)) l (nhds a) ‚Üí
      Filter.Tendsto (fun y => y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) l l ‚Üí
        Filter.Tendsto (fun y => (f (y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) - d) / (y - x)) l (nhds a)
name: tendsto_apply_add_mul_sq_div_sub
docString: This theorem states that if the expression `(f y - f x) / (y - x)` tends to a certain limit as `y` approaches `x` (possibly only from one side or along certain lines), then the same limiting behavior holds for the expression `(f (y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) - d) / (y - x)`. This is essentially saying that adding a small perturbation `(c * (y - x) ^ 2)` to the argument of `f` in the numerator doesn't change the limiting behavior. This theorem is particularly useful in the study of almost everywhere differentiability of monotone functions, where such perturbations often arise.

  (‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), AEMeasurable (f n)) ‚Üí

Shows that
$\sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} (e^{X})^k = \sum_{p = 0}^{\infty} \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{k^p}{p!}X^p$.

name: PowerSeries.exp_pow_sum
docString:
Shows that
$\sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} (e^{X})^k = \sum_{p = 0}^{\infty} \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{k^p}{p!}X^p$.

    {T : CategoryTheory.Monad C} ‚Üí
      {J : Type u} ‚Üí

          (D : CategoryTheory.Functor J (CategoryTheory.Monad.Algebra T)) ‚Üí
            (c : CategoryTheory.Limits.Cone (CategoryTheory.Functor.comp D (CategoryTheory.Monad.forget T))) ‚Üí

A convenient way to show that a binary fan is a limit.

type:
{C : Type u} ‚Üí
  [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{v, u} C] ‚Üí
    {X Y : C} ‚Üí
      (s : CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan X Y) ‚Üí
        (lift : {T : C} ‚Üí (T ‚ü∂ X) ‚Üí (T ‚ü∂ Y) ‚Üí (T ‚ü∂ s.pt)) ‚Üí
          (‚àÄ {T : C} (f : T ‚ü∂ X) (g : T ‚ü∂ Y),
              CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp (lift f g) (CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan.fst s) = f) ‚Üí
            (‚àÄ {T : C} (f : T ‚ü∂ X) (g : T ‚ü∂ Y),
                CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp (lift f g) (CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan.snd s) = g) ‚Üí
              (‚àÄ {T : C} (f : T ‚ü∂ X) (g : T ‚ü∂ Y) (m : T ‚ü∂ s.pt),
                  CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp m (CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan.fst s) = f ‚Üí
                    CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp m (CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan.snd s) = g ‚Üí m = lift f g) ‚Üí
                CategoryTheory.Limits.IsLimit s
name: CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan.IsLimit.mk
docString: A convenient way to show that a binary fan is a limit.

If `(f y - f x) / (y - x)` converges to a limit as `y` tends to `x`, then the same goes if
`y` is shifted a little bit, i.e., `f (y + (y-x)^2) - f x) / (y - x)` converges to the same limit.
This lemma contains a slightly more general version of this statement (where one considers
convergence along some subfilter, typically `ùìù[<] x` or `ùìù[>] x`) tailored to the application
to almost everywhere differentiability of monotone functions.

type:
‚àÄ {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {x a c d : ‚Ñù} {l : Filter ‚Ñù},
  l ‚â§ nhdsWithin x {x}·∂ú ‚Üí
    Filter.Tendsto (fun y => (f y - d) / (y - x)) l (nhds a) ‚Üí
      Filter.Tendsto (fun y => y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) l l ‚Üí
        Filter.Tendsto (fun y => (f (y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) - d) / (y - x)) l (nhds a)
name: tendsto_apply_add_mul_sq_div_sub
docString:
If `(f y - f x) / (y - x)` converges to a limit as `y` tends to `x`, then the same goes if

This lemma contains a slightly more general version of this statement (where one considers
convergence along some subfilter, typically `ùìù[<] x` or `ùìù[>] x`) tailored to the application
to almost everywhere differentiability of monotone functions.

type:
